What's happening?
â€¢ mkdir my-oblit-app creates a new folder called "my-oblit-app"
â€¢ cd my-oblit-app navigates into that folder

Pro Tip: You can name your project anything! Common names: oblit-server, game-server, chat-app, etc.
h3(Initialize NPM Project) Now, let's initialize this directory as an NPM project: ![code](npm init -y)!++// This command creates a package.json file in your directory. This file is the manifest of your projectâ€”it tracks scripts, dependencies, metadata, and more.
What you'll see: A new file called package.json will be created with default values. You can edit this file later if needed.
!(line) h2(ğŸ“¥ Step 2: Install OBLIT) Now for the exciting partâ€”installing OBLIT! Add the OBLIT library to your project from the NPM registry: ![code](npm install oblit)!++//
ğŸ¯ Zero-Dependency Philosophy

While this command creates a node_modules folder, OBLIT itself adds zero external dependencies. This ensures:
  • âœ… Minimal attack surface
  • âœ… Fast installation
  • âœ… Lightweight footprint
  • âœ… No dependency conflicts

Your node_modules folder will be tiny!
h3(Verify Installation) Let's verify that OBLIT was installed correctly: ![code](node -e "console.log(require('oblit'))")!++// If you see an object with Server, Client, and OP properties, congratulations! OBLIT is ready to use. !(line) h2(ğŸ’» Step 3: Your First OBLIT Server) Let's create your first OBLIT server. Create a file named server.js in your project directory: ![code](// server.js - Your first OBLIT server const { Server } = require('oblit'); // 1. Create a server instance bound to port 8080 const app = new Server({ port: 8080 }); // 2. Listen for incoming data packets app.on('data', (message, socket) => { console.log(`ğŸ“¨ Packet received from ${socket.remoteAddress}`); console.log(`ğŸ“¦ Data:`, message); // 3. Broadcast a response to all connected clients const reply = `Server received: ${message}`; app.bc(reply); }); // 4. Listen for client connections app.on('connect', (socket) => { console.log(`âœ… New client connected: ${socket.remoteAddress}:${socket.remotePort}`); }); // 5. Listen for client disconnections app.on('disconnect', (socket) => { console.log(`âŒ Client disconnected: ${socket.remoteAddress}:${socket.remotePort}`); }); // 6. Start the server app.st(() => { console.log('ğŸš€ OBLIT Server is ready on port 8080!'); console.log('ğŸ“¡ Waiting for connections...'); });)!++// h3(Code Breakdown) Let's understand what each part does:
Line(s)What It DoesExplanation
const { Server } = require('oblit')Imports OBLITLoads the Server class from the OBLIT package
new Server({ port: 8080 })Creates server instancePrepares a TCP server that will listen on port 8080
app.on('data', ...)Data event handlerRuns whenever a client sends data. Receives the message and the socket.
app.bc(reply)Broadcast messageSends the reply to all connected clients simultaneously
app.on('connect', ...)Connection eventRuns when a new client connects to the server
app.on('disconnect', ...)Disconnection eventRuns when a client disconnects
app.st(...)Start serverActually starts listening on the port. Callback runs when ready.

We'll create a simple client to connect to it. h3(Create a Test Client) Create a file named client.js: ![code](// client.js - Simple test client const { Client } = require('oblit'); // Create a client that connects to localhost:8080 const client = new Client('127.0.0.1:8080'); // Connect to the server client.cn(() => { console.log('âœ… Connected to server!'); // Send a test message client.snd('Hello from client!'); // Listen for server responses client.on('data', (message) => { console.log('ğŸ“¨ Server says:', message); }); // Send periodic messages (every 2 seconds) setInterval(() => { client.snd(`Ping at ${new Date().toLocaleTimeString()}`); }, 2000); }); // Handle errors client.on('error', (error) => { console.error('âŒ Client error:', error.message); });)!++// h3(Run Your Server) Open a terminal in your project directory and run: ![code](node server.js)!++// You should see:
ğŸš€ OBLIT Server is ready on port 8080!
ğŸ“¡ Waiting for connections...
h3(Run Your Client) Open a **second terminal** in the same directory and run: ![code](node client.js)!++// Watch both terminals! You should see messages flowing between the client and server.
ğŸ‰ Congratulations!

You've successfully created your first OBLIT application! You now have:
  • âœ… A running TCP server
  • âœ… A client that can send and receive messages
  • âœ… Real-time bidirectional communication
  • âœ… Broadcast functionality
!(line) h2(ğŸ“š Next Steps) Now that you have OBLIT installed and running, here's what to explore next:

ğŸ“– Protocol Anatomy

Learn how OBLIT's binary protocol works at the byte level.

ğŸ”Œ Server API

Explore all available server methods and events.

ğŸ’¬ Chat Tutorial

Build a real-time chat application step-by-step.

ğŸ® Game Server Tutorial

Create a high-performance multiplayer game server.

!(line) h2(ğŸ› Troubleshooting) EADDRINUSE: address already in use:
Solution: Change the port number in your server code: const app = new Server({ port: 3000 });

Or find what's using port 8080 and stop it:
// Windows: netstat -ano | findstr :8080
// Linux/Mac: lsof -i :8080
h3(Cannot Find Module 'oblit') If you see Error: Cannot find module 'oblit':
Solution: Make sure you've run npm install oblit in the same directory where your server.js file is located.
![tip](Need more help? Check out the **[API Reference](#!/server_api)** for detailed method documentation, or explore the **[Tutorials](#!/tut_chat)** for complete working examples.)!++
